                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                </gmd:CI_Citation>
            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>Swim Drink Fish was founded in 2001, and originally had the name ‘Lake Ontario Waterkeeper’. The mission was to protect the watersheds in Southern Ontario, where the founders, Mark Mattson and Krystyn Tully, grew up. The organization uses a multidisciplinary approach in applying environmental law, science, storytelling and technology to educate and empower people to protect their local waters. Currently, Swim Drink Fish is focused on safeguarding the waters of the The Great Lakes and other Canadian waterbodies.

The Lake Erie - Niagara Community Monitoring Hub is one of five across the Great Lakes and is part of a four year citizen science project by Swim Drink Fish, established with funding from Environment and Climate Change Canada's Great Lake Protection Initiative. The Lake Erie - Niagara Hub was established in 2019 in collaboration with Niagara College and the Niagara Coastal Community Collaborative. By engaging the Niagara community in citizen science, the hub promotes stewardship of Lake Erie and provides low-cost, reliable water quality monitoring data for recreational water bodies across the north shore of Lake Erie.

Recreational water samples are collected once a week by Swim Drink Fish staff and trained volunteer citizen scientists. Samples are analyzed for E. coli in lab space provided by Niagara College at its Niagara-on-the-Lake campus using IDEXX lab equipment. E.coli is straightforward to measure and is the most widely used indicator for assessing recreational water quality in the world. For these reasons, Swim Drink Fish chose to focus on E.coli measurements, despite the wide variety of pollutants that are present in natural waterbodies.
Recreational beach water results are all shared with the public through the Swim Guide app, a Swim Drink Fish initiative, and the raw data is made available on Swim Drink Fish’s Open Data Portal for recreational water quality.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>
            <gmd:credit gco:nilReason="missing"/>

                    <gmd:temporalElement>

name: 10-25976-0r51-rq75
notes:
Swim Drink Fish was founded in 2001, and originally had the name ‘Lake Ontario Waterkeeper’. The mission was to protect the watersheds in Southern Ontario, where the founders, Mark Mattson and Krystyn Tully, grew up. The organization uses a multidisciplinary approach in applying environmental law, science, storytelling and technology to educate and empower people to protect their local waters. Currently, Swim Drink Fish is focused on safeguarding the waters of the The Great Lakes and other Canadian waterbodies.

The Lake Erie - Niagara Community Monitoring Hub is one of five across the Great Lakes and is part of a four year citizen science project by Swim Drink Fish, established with funding from Environment and Climate Change Canada's Great Lake Protection Initiative. The Lake Erie - Niagara Hub was established in 2019 in collaboration with Niagara College and the Niagara Coastal Community Collaborative. By engaging the Niagara community in citizen science, the hub promotes stewardship of Lake Erie and provides low-cost, reliable water quality monitoring data for recreational water bodies across the north shore of Lake Erie.

Recreational water samples are collected once a week by Swim Drink Fish staff and trained volunteer citizen scientists. Samples are analyzed for E. coli in lab space provided by Niagara College at its Niagara-on-the-Lake campus using IDEXX lab equipment. E.coli is straightforward to measure and is the most widely used indicator for assessing recreational water quality in the world. For these reasons, Swim Drink Fish chose to focus on E.coli measurements, despite the wide variety of pollutants that are present in natural waterbodies.
Recreational beach water results are all shared with the public through the Swim Guide app, a Swim Drink Fish initiative, and the raw data is made available on Swim Drink Fish’s Open Data Portal for recreational water quality.

notes_translated.en:
Swim Drink Fish was founded in 2001, and originally had the name ‘Lake Ontario Waterkeeper’. The mission was to protect the watersheds in Southern Ontario, where the founders, Mark Mattson and Krystyn Tully, grew up. The organization uses a multidisciplinary approach in applying environmental law, science, storytelling and technology to educate and empower people to protect their local waters. Currently, Swim Drink Fish is focused on safeguarding the waters of the The Great Lakes and other Canadian waterbodies.

The Lake Erie - Niagara Community Monitoring Hub is one of five across the Great Lakes and is part of a four year citizen science project by Swim Drink Fish, established with funding from Environment and Climate Change Canada's Great Lake Protection Initiative. The Lake Erie - Niagara Hub was established in 2019 in collaboration with Niagara College and the Niagara Coastal Community Collaborative. By engaging the Niagara community in citizen science, the hub promotes stewardship of Lake Erie and provides low-cost, reliable water quality monitoring data for recreational water bodies across the north shore of Lake Erie.

Recreational water samples are collected once a week by Swim Drink Fish staff and trained volunteer citizen scientists. Samples are analyzed for E. coli in lab space provided by Niagara College at its Niagara-on-the-Lake campus using IDEXX lab equipment. E.coli is straightforward to measure and is the most widely used indicator for assessing recreational water quality in the world. For these reasons, Swim Drink Fish chose to focus on E.coli measurements, despite the wide variety of pollutants that are present in natural waterbodies.
Recreational beach water results are all shared with the public through the Swim Guide app, a Swim Drink Fish initiative, and the raw data is made available on Swim Drink Fish’s Open Data Portal for recreational water quality.
notes_translated.fr:
Swim Drink Fish a été fondée en 2001 et portait à l'origine le nom de « Lake Ontario Waterkeeper ». La mission était de protéger les bassins versants du sud de l'Ontario, où les fondateurs, Mark Mattson et Krystyn Tully, ont grandi. L'organisation utilise une approche multidisciplinaire dans l'application du droit de l'environnement, de la science, de la narration et de la technologie afin d'éduquer et de donner aux gens les moyens de protéger leurs eaux locales. À l'heure actuelle, Swim Drink Fish se concentre sur la protection des eaux des Grands Lacs et d'autres plans d'eau canadiens.

Le centre de surveillance communautaire du lac Érié et du Niagara est l'un des cinq centres de surveillance communautaire des Grands Lacs et fait partie d'un projet scientifique citoyen de quatre ans de Swim Drink Fish, établi grâce au financement de l'Initiative de protection des Grands Lacs d'Environnement et Changement climatique Canada. Le hub Lake Erie - Niagara a été créé en 2019 en collaboration avec le Niagara College et le Niagara Coastal Community Collaborative. En faisant participer la communauté de Niagara à la science citoyenne, le centre favorise l'intendance du lac Érié et fournit des données de surveillance de la qualité de l'eau fiables et peu coûteuses pour les plans d'eau récréatifs de la rive nord du lac Érié.

Des échantillons d'eau récréative sont prélevés une fois par semaine par le personnel de Swim Drink Fish et des scientifiques citoyens bénévoles formés. Les échantillons sont analysés pour détecter la présence d'E. coli dans un espace de laboratoire fourni par le Niagara College sur son campus de Niagara-on-the-Lake à l'aide de l'équipement de laboratoire IDEXX. La bactérie E. coli est facile à mesurer et constitue l'indicateur le plus utilisé pour évaluer la qualité des eaux utilisées à des fins récréatives dans le monde. Pour ces raisons, Swim Drink Fish a choisi de se concentrer sur les mesures d'E. coli, malgré la grande variété de polluants présents dans les plans d'eau naturels.
Les résultats relatifs à l'eau des plages récréatives sont tous partagés avec le public via l'application Swim Guide, une initiative de Swim Drink Fish, et les données brutes sont mises à disposition sur le portail de données ouvertes de Swim Drink Fish pour la qualité des eaux récréatives.

notes_translation_method.fr: Description text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.
